To do this, log in as SFAdmin, navigate to Admin Center, and then navigate to AI Service Administration. Activate the Ask HR Policy toggle as shown below, and ensure the activated service is saved by logging out and revisiting the site.

 

Image 01

 

 

Tip: You can try activating it with a proxy login to sfadmin. If the service does not allow it, we recommend logging in as sfadmin and activating the service.

1.2 Role-Based Permission Assign Manage Document Grounding

Now, let us activate the SAP SuccessFactors permission in the system to Manage Document Grounding services. This permission will enable us to map files based on your requirements, such as Company, Location, Role, Company, Employee Type, Job Title, Pay Grade, Cost Center, and many more.

To assign this role to users, navigate to Manage Permission Roles, select the group to assign the permission, and, in my case, I have opted forSFCC Super Admin. Click Next.

 

Image 02

Now, search for Document Grounding. You should be able to see the option under Manage AI Capabilities. Select the option ‘Manage Document Grounding,’ click on Next, and Save the settings.

 

Image 03

To test it, you can now log out of the system and log back in. This will allow you to refresh the roles in the system. You can now search for ‘Document Grounding’ and should see the new option ‘Manage Document Grounding’.

Image 04

2. Register a new application & add the dependencies in SAP Cloud Identity Services(IAS).

In this step, we will create a new application to support the Document Grounding setup. We will generate a new Client ID andClient Secret, which will be used in destinations and other places. To set up this application, you can log in to your SAP Cloud Identity Services used by your Joule and SAP SuccessFactors system.

Navigate to Application & Resources -> click onCreate -> and enter the following details below, and click on Create.

  • Display Name: SFSF-T1-DGS (please note the name that you use, as we will be using it later. In my case, I am using SFSF; T1 is my SFSF system’s name)
  • Type: SAP SuccessFactors Solution
  • Protocol Type: OpenID Connect

Image 05

Now, click on Client Authentication and, in the Secret section, click Add to create new credentials.

Image 06

I am using the same name as the description, setting the expiry to ‘Never’, and selecting all the APIs listed below. Then, I click on ‘Save’.

 

Image 07

This will generate a new Client ID and Client Secret. Please make a note of this value using the copy button.

Note: This will not be displayed again, so please secure them as we will be using them later.

 

Image 08

In the application, click on ‘Provided APIs’, then click ‘Add’ and enter the values as shown below. Save the changes.

  • Name: sf_technical_access (recommended to keep the same value)
  • Description: For Technical Access to SF (can be free text)

Image 09

Now, click on Dependencies, then click Add. Enter the following details as shown below, and click Save.

  • Dependency Name: DGS-SF-Call (mandatory to use the same name)
  • Application: Select your SAP SuccessFactors system from the dropdown list (If you don’t see your SuccessFactors system, you may need to do the OIDC migration)
  • API: sf_technical_access (the API name which was created in the previous step)

Image 10

3. Manage OIDC OAuth Client Application in SAP SuccessFactors – Security Center

As part of the setup, we will now need to configure the OIDC OAuth Client Application in the SAP SuccessFactors system. Please log in to your SAP SFSF system and navigate to Security Center, and click on Manage OIDC OAuth Client Application.

 

Image 11

Click "Register" and enter the following details.

  • Application Map Name: SFSF-T1-DGS (same name as configured in the SAP Cloud Identity Services)
  • Client ID: from your SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Application Type: DOCUMENT_GROUNDING (from the drop-down)

    Once you enter the details, click 'Register'. 

Image 12

You should be able to see the details as shown below.

Image 13

4. Create App Registration for Document Grounding with Application Permission (validate your existing setup)

As of the new release, we are currently supporting Application Permissions forMicrosoft Graph, and this is required for the Metadata with documents.

This section is required only if you have set up your Microsoft SharePoint Application registration with Delegated Permission. If you are using an existing setup, please validate it, and you may need to delete and recreate the application. You may refer to our previous blog for complete setup information.

I have highlighted some key information here. Your application should be set up with Application Permission as shown below.

Image 14

You should have the API permissions for "Sites.Read.All" or "Sites.Selected" based on your requirements and the role "User.Read.All", as shown below.

Image 15

You have generated a Client Secret value and have it saved for further setup.

Image 16

Note: Next section 5 is required only if you have selected “Sites.Selected” instead of “Sites.Read.all” permissions.

 

5. Fetch the SharePoint Site ID and grant read access to the site

We will now generate the Site ID for the Microsoft SharePoint that you plan to use. To do this, we will work with your BRUNO client. I have pasted the cURL commands to make it easier for you to create the required GET/POST requests.

5.1 Get Microsoft Token

In the BRUNO client, create a new collection and enter the request name as GetMicrosoftToken, and click on the from cURL option and paste the code that you see below.

Name: GetMicrosoftToken (Bearer Token) 

CURL Command to Details from MS Entra:

 

curl --request POST \
--url https://login.microsoftonline.com/<<TENANTID>>/oauth2/v2.0/token \
--header 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
--header 'content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
--data client_id=<<ClientID>> \
--data 'client_secret=<<ClientSecret>>' \
--data scope=https://graph.microsoft.com/.default \
--data grant_type=client_credentials

 

Once you import the cURL code, you can either modify the values before you import, or once you import the collection. You'll need to edit the highlighted values.

Image 17

You should be able to see the details as follows.

Image 18

Now we are good to trigger a call, click on the go/execute button, which will generate an access_token as shown below.

Image 19

 

5.2 Create a collection to GetSiteID

Collection Name: GetSiteID

 

curl --request GET \
--url https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/sites/<<Sharepoint_URI_HOST>>:/sites/<<SITE_NAME>> \
--header 'authorization: Bearer <<ACCESS TOKEN VALUE>>'

 

Note: The Bearer token value is the access token value that was generated in the previous collection GetSiteID.

You can modify the highlighted details before importing the cURL. 

Image 20

You should be able to see the details as shown below. Now, we are ready to click on 'Go/Execute'.

Image 21

You will be able to see the value of “id”. Please copy the entire value, as we will be using it later.

Image 22

5.3 Graph Explorer

Graph Explorer is a developer tool that enables you to explore Microsoft Graph APIs. Here, we will use the developer tool to generate, set the required permissions, and grant consent for the setup process.

Please use the link below to log in with your admin role as shown below.

https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/graph-explorer

Image 23

You can click on any of the Getting Started requests shown below and edit the values as needed.

Change from GET to POST and change the URL as below:

https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/sites/<<value-from-BRUNO-GetSiteID-IDValue>>/permissions

Image 24

Once you modify the values above, we will need to work on the Request Body. We will now need the App Registration name from your MS Entra, as shown below.  

Image 25

Use the value of the body as shown below:

 
{
"roles": ["read"],
"grantedToIdentities": [
{
"application": {
"id": "your-app-client-id",
"displayName": "Your App Name"
}
}
]
}

 

Image 26

Once you add the values, you can click on Modify Permissions, click on Open the permissions panel, and you should be able to see a new window.

Image 27

You can click on Consent for the option "Sites.FullControl.All"; this will open a new window.

 

Image 28

Select the 'Consent on behalf of your organization' option and click 'Accept'.

Image 29

You should be able to see the notification Success as shown below.

Image 30

 

Now, click on the Request Headers and add the key - Content-Type and value as application/json as shown below, and click on Run query.

Image 31

Look for the 'Created-201' success message, as shown below.

Image 32

This now completes the setup on Microsoft, and the required permissions are granted and created.

 

6. Create a BTP Subaccount Destination

We will now be creating two new destinations to establish communication between the systems.

  • SFSF-T1-DG-Context-Setup
  • SFSF-T1-DG-Metadata-Destination

6.1 Destination for Document Grounding Context

You can create this destination setup manually or download the attached files to this blog and modify the values. Here, I have shown the details on how to create it manually.

Please navigate to our SAP BTP Subaccount, click on Destinations, and click on Create and select From Scratch and click on Create.

Image 33

Enter the following details: 

Parameter

Value

Destination Name

SFSF-T1-DG-Context-Setup

Type

HTTP

Description

Free Text

Proxy Type

Internet

URL

Your Microsoft SharePoint URL

Eg: https://hostname.com/sitename

Authentication

OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID

Client ID from your MS Entra – Application Registration Overview section.

Eg: sfsf-dg-contexual-setup overview will have the Client ID in the overview section

Client Secret

Value – from Certificates & Secrets that we created in step 4

Token Service URL

Enter the value as shown below:

https://login.microsoft.com/<<Microsoft-Entra-Tenant-ID>>/oauth2/v2.0/token

Token Service URL Type

Dedicated

 

Additional Properties:

 

Parameter 

Value 

scope (all lower case) 

https://graph.microsoft.com/.default 

 Your setup should be as shown below, create the settings and click on Create.  

 

Image 34

You can click on ‘Check Connection’ to validate the setup, and you should see a success message.  

Image 35

6.2 Destination for Document Grounding Metadata  

You create this destination setup manually or download the files attached to the bottom of this blog and modify the values. Here, I have shown the details on how to create it manually.  

Navigate to our SAP BTP Subaccount, click on Destinations, and click on Create and select From Scratch and click on Create.  

Enter the following values: 

 

Parameter 

Value 

Destination Name 

SFSF-T1-DG-Metadata-Destination 

Type 

HTTP 

Description 

Free Text 

Proxy Type 

Internet 

URL 

You should be entering the value from your SFSF system APIs.  

Syntax: https://<<SFSF-API-Domain>>/rest/foundation/intelligence/generativeai/explainpay/v1/dg-pipeline/metadata?aiUseCase=HR%20Policy%20QA 

 Example in my case it’s from SFSF Preview: 

https://api55preview.sapsf.eu/rest/foundation/intelligence/generativeai/explainpay/v1/dg-pipeline/metadata?aiUseCase=HR%20Policy%20QA 

Tip: you can refer to SAP Note: 2215682 - SuccessFactors API URLs and external IPs to find your Tenant API URL based on your Data Center 

Authentication 

OAuth2ClientCredentials 

Client ID 

Client ID value from SAP Cloud Identity Services in step 2 

Client Secret 

Client Secret value from SAP Cloud Identity Services in step 2 

Token Service URL 

Your IAS URL, as shown below 

Syntax: https://<<SAP-CIS-URL>>/oauth2/token 

 Example: https://asxxxxxozz1.accounts.cloud.sap/oauth2/token 

Token Service URL Type 

Dedicated 

 

Additional Parameters:

 

Parameter 

Value 

tokenService.body.resource 

urn:sap:identity:application:provider:name:DGS-SF-Call 

pageSize 

50 or 100  

Recommendation for SAP SuccessFactors: keep the number below 100 for better performance.  

Reason: This variable is required to recursively ingest all documents in chunks of mentioned number of documents while creating the pipeline  

Once you create the destination as shown below, you can click on Create.  

 

Image 36

 

 

Finally, you should be able to see both these destinations.  

Image 37

7. Create a new Pipeline for your Metadata Document Grounding 

As mentioned above, you should be creating a new pipeline in case of an existing setup. In my case I had an existing pipeline which I deleted, and now creating a new pipeline. You can either look at my original blog post for Document Grounding setup or continue using the steps below, feel free to skip the steps in case not applicable. However, please note, if you are doing the metadata setup, it is mandatory to create a new pipeline.  

To generate a Certificate and Key files you can look at step c. Copy / Edit the Certificate values to support *.crt and *.key values and to bearer token refer to step 8.2 Get Bearer Token, and create a pipeline you can follow the steps below.  

If you have the same BRUNO collections created in the past, ensure the certificate is not expired.  

You can create the collection using the following cURL and modify the highlighted values.  

 

curl --request POST \
--url https://<<MTLS URL>>/pipeline/api/v1/pipeline \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <<Bearer Token>>' \
--header 'content-type: application/json' \
--data '{
"type": "MSSharePoint",
"configuration": {
"destination": "SFSF-T1-DG-Context-Setup",
"sharePoint": {
"site": {
"name": "<<SITENAME>>"
}
}
},
"metadata": {
"dataRepositoryMetadata": [
{
"key": "lob",
"value": ["sfsf"]
}
],
"destination": "SFSF-T1-DG-Metadata-Destination"
}
}'

 

Create the BRUNO post request as shown below.  

Image 38 

 

 

Once the values are modified, you can execute the POST command and generate the pipeline id.  

Image 39

 8. Configure Supported Metadata for User Data Field Mapping in SAP SuccessFactors  

Now that the pipeline is newly created, we can go ahead and set up the metadata mapping for each file based on the user context. Let’s now navigate to the SAP SuccessFactors system, navigate to Manage Document Grounding, and enter the value that was generated in step 5.2 Create a collection to Get Site Name, as shown below, along with Client ID, Client Secret, and Tenant ID from Microsoft Entra. Once the values are entered, click Connect.  

Note:  

  • “SharePoint Site ID” supports options with both SharePoint Site ID and SharePoint URL.  
  • For the “Folder Path” field, only the root path is supported at this point in time “/” the entire site’s documents will be considered for the ingestion. 

 

Image 40

 You should now be able to see the mapping options. In my demo, I will demonstrate only one value: Country. I have modified all other values to 'Unable to Map' except for the Country. I have updated it to Country/Region. Now, click on Save.

 

 

Image 41

In the next page, you can click on Add Metadata, and you should be able to see all the files in your MS SharePoint.  

 

Image 42 
 

The image below helps you understand how the folders and file structure appear in your SAP SuccessFactors system, which are stored in your MS SharePoint.   

Image 43

I am picking up the file related to English and configuring to a country. To configure it, select the files and click on Next.  

 Image 44

On the next page, we will need to enter the string that we need to tag. This value can be found in your Employee Profile, as shown in the image below. I am picking up the value for one of the employees, and the Country is “United States”. You can enter multiple locations based on your requirements for the documents you need, with specifics, and click ‘Add’.  

Image 45

This should complete the doc metadata configuration. As next steps, you may wait for at most 24 hours to get the metadata updated in the DGS pipeline, or you may manually trigger the DGS pipeline i.e., Step 9 below. 

 

Image 46

9. Trigger the Pipeline post Metadata setup in your SAP SFSF 

This process is required when you add and/or change your metadata, as it is a manual approach at this time. Otherwise, you have to wait for at most 24 hours to get the metadata updated in the DGS pipeline. 

To trigger the metadata, you can create the BRUNO collection with the help of cURL as shown below and ensure the highlighted values are modified as required.  

Pipeline Name: Pipeline Trigger 

 

curl --request POST \
--url https://<<MTLS_URI>>/pipeline/api/v1/pipeline/trigger \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <<TOKEN_VALUE>>’ \
--header 'content-type: application/json' \
--data '{
"pipelineId": "<<PIPELINEID>>",
"metadataOnly": false
}'

 

Once you have the values, you can click on go/execute the collection.  

Image 47

You should be able to see the success message with the timeline of last completed as shown below.   

Image 48

You can also check this with GET Pipeline, as demonstrated below with the URL changes in the collections. Add the Pipeline ID followed by the value shown in the image below. You should be able to see the document indexed along with the country values.   

Image 49

 

10. Test your Policy settings 

Finally, we are at the testing stage, you may now login to the users who are from the “United States” and the file will be working only for these employees as shown below.   

Image 50

 

If employees from other countries or regions ask the same question, it will fail with a message as shown below.   

Image 51

 

 This completes the setup process and a demo of how metadata / contextualization-based document grounding works for your employees.  

Happy learning!!! 

Cheers, 

Nagesh Caparthy 

 Credits: This blog post has been written in collaboration with the SAP SuccessFactors Business AI Team (Leo Chen, Ramesha R N, Sumanth Pullagura Govinda Mani) and SAP AI Engineering Team (Sudarshan Pavanje) 

 

11. Appendix: 

If you want to configure additional metadata, follow the images below and trigger the pipeline for metadata as shown.  

 

 

Image 52

 

Image 53

 

 

Image 54

 

 

Image 55

In case of other users looking for similar information: 

 

Image 56

entry.title: SAP Joule Data Quality KPIs: Auto-Generates and Measures KPI's to fix broken SAP Master Data Records
entry.content:
How SAP Joule can Turn Data Quality KPIs into Real Business Control

*Views expressed here are my own and doesn't represent any entity.

Every SAP-driven organization knows this truth — even if it’s rarely said out loud:

Most business risks don’t start with strategy.

They start with bad data.

A missing tax code. A duplicate customer. An outdated BOM. An untraceable ESG metric. Individually, they look small. Collectively, they erode compliance, margins, and trust.

This is where SAP Joule changes the game — not by adding more dashboards, but by turning data quality into an intelligent, business-aware control system.

 

The Old World: Measuring Data Too Late

In traditional SAP environments, data quality is:

  • Measured after the fact

  • Reported at aggregate level

  • Owned by IT, not the business

By the time leadership sees a data quality issue, the impact has already landed:

  • Regulatory rework

  • Production delays

  • Revenue leakage

  • Audit findings

Joule can flip this model by working at the level where risk is actually created — the SAP data object.

 

How Joule can Generate KPIs for Real SAP Objects (Not Abstract Metrics)?

SAP landscapes are built on concrete objects:

  • Material Master (MARA, MARC)

  • Business Partner (BUT000)

  • Bills of Material (STPO)

  • Pricing Conditions (KONV)

  • Excise & Customs data (SAP GTS)

  • ESG attributes (SAP EH&S)

Joule doesn’t need to guess what to measure — it reads how the business actually uses these objects.

Example 1: Material Master (SAP S/4HANA – PP/MM)

The problem: A manufacturing site experiences frequent production stoppages due to incorrect or incomplete material data.

What Joule can do :

  • Identifies which material fields are mandatory for production and quality

  • Generates KPIs such as:

Material master completeness %
BOM consistency across plants
Production posting error rate

What leadership sees:

“Three material attributes are causing 80% of production rework in two factories.”

Not a metric — a decision trigger.

Enter SAP Joule: Data Quality That Thinks Like a Business Partner

SAP Joule brings generative AI into the SAP stack — not as a chatbot, but as an intelligent orchestration layer across data, processes, and controls.

When applied to data quality, Joule can enable three game-changing capabilities:

Automatic KPI generation for every SAP data object
Context-aware thresholds instead of one-size-fits-all rules
Business-language explanations of data risk

Let’s break this down.

Generating Data Quality KPIs for Every SAP Data Object

SAP systems are built on standard data objects. Traditionally, teams manually decide:

Which fields matter
Which KPIs to track
Which thresholds apply

With Joule, this can become intelligent and automated.

How Joule can do in future?

Joule analyzes:

SAP object metadata (tables, fields, relationships)
Usage patterns (how often data is used downstream)
Process criticality (e.g., regulatory vs operational)
Historical data issues and corrections

From this, Joule can propose KPIs automatically, such as:

Completeness (% of mandatory fields populated)
Accuracy (rule-based and cross-object consistency)
Duplication rates
Timeliness (data freshness vs SLA)
Conformity to country-specific rules

And it does this per object, not per report. It can measure Thresholds That Actually Reflect Business Risk. A 95% completeness score doesn’t mean the same thing for:

ESG reporting
Excise tax determination
Internal planning data

This is where Joule goes beyond traditional data quality tools.

Dynamic, risk-based thresholds

Joule can:

Adjust thresholds by market, plant, or regulation
Flag materiality (which data issues truly matter)
Learn from outcomes (e.g., audit findings, rework, penalties)

Example: A missing material attribute in a non-regulated market → warning

The same issue in a regulated market → critical breach

Instead of “red/amber/green and technical language for issues” , leaders see the impact of data quality issue on business.

 

Making Data Quality Understandable to Humans

Data quality often fails because it’s explained in technical language.

Joule changes that from metrics to meaning. Rather than showing:

“2.1% duplication rate in Business Partner data”

Joule can explain:

“Duplicate customer records are increasing invoice rework and delaying cash collection in two key markets.”

This turns data governance into decision support and KPIs into actionable insight and IT controls into business confidence.

Continuous Monitoring, Not Periodic Audits

With Joule integrated into SAP:

KPIs update continuously
Threshold breaches trigger explanations, not just alerts
Data owners receive context, not noise

This supports:

S/4HANA transformations
SOX and regulatory assurance
ESG credibility

Data quality becomes a living system, not a quarterly report.

Why This Matters for Leadership

For executives, the value proposition is straightforward and compelling:

Mitigate Risk: Significantly reduces regulatory surprises and enable swift, proactive responses to emerging threats.
Optimise Operations: Eliminates operational friction, driving greater efficiency and smoother processes.
Bolster Trust: Cultivates unwavering confidence in critical business data and insights.
 

In essence, SAP Joule transforms high-quality data from a desirable aspiration into a foundational, strategic operating capability.

This marks a profound shift in data quality management. We move beyond outdated practices of merely policing data fields, escalating issues it IT language, enforcing rigid rules, or assigning blame. Instead, Joule empowers organisations to:

Understand Impact: Clearly articulate the business consequences of data issues.
Prioritise Strategically: Focus resources on what truly matters to the business.
Protect Value: Safeguard enterprise assets and drive growth at scale.

This isn't just about achieving better data quality; it's about establishing superior business control.

entry.title: SAP Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (PCE) - Detailed steps
entry.content:
SAP Joule is SAP’s next-generation generative AI assistant designed to transform how users interact with SAP systems. Integrated across the SAP ecosystem, Joule enables natural language conversations that help users navigate applications, retrieve business insights, and perform transactions without traditional menus or manual steps. By understanding real business context, Joule guides users to the right Fiori apps, executes tasks such as displaying purchase orders or creating sales documents, and provides intelligent insights drawn from S/4HANA and other SAP solutions. This elevates user productivity, reduces training effort, and delivers a more intuitive, conversational SAP experience.  

This guide walks through the setup of Joule for an SAP S/4HANA Cloud PCE system. It is based on hands-on implementation experience and is written to help consultants and administrators perform the setup efficiently. 

Capabilities of Joule 

SAP Joule offers three major capability categories that help users interact with SAP systems through natural language: 

  • Transactional Capabilities 

Joule can perform business transactions on behalf of the user by invoking S/4HANA APIs and Fiori applications. 

  • Navigational Capabilities 

Joule can navigate users to the correct SAP Fiori apps based on their request. 

  • Informational Capabilities 

Joule provides conversational insights and general information from SAP documentation and system context. 

Architecture Diagram 

 

SAP Joule is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition starting from version 2021 and above. 

How to Get Access to SAP Joule 

  • New RISE contracts → auto entitled. 
  • Existing RISE customers → request entitlement from Account Executive. 

Prerequisites 

  • SAP BTP with Joule, work zone, cloud identity service, cloud foundry services 
  • SAP Cloud Connector 
  • SAP Cloud identity services 
  • SAP S/4HANA private cloud system 

 

Let’s get started with the configuration. 

We will divide the configuration steps into four main parts.. 

1. SAP BTP configuration 

1.1 Validate S/4HANA private cloud system is included in the landscape. 

1.2 Make sure the entitlements for Joule, Work zone, and Cloud identity services are available 

1.3 Create a subaccount for Joule and include the above-mentioned services in the subaccount. 

Tip: Subaccount should be created in a region where the Cloud identity service is located if we are using only one subaccount for all services. If we are using a separate subaccount for cloud identity services, then we must choose a region which is same or near to S/4HANA system for the Joule subaccount. 

 1.4 Establish trust with cloud identity services 

 1.5 Run Joule Booster 

 

Select S/4HANA cloud private edition as the capability and include work zone and cloud identity services in the integration setup and complete the booster run 

 

 

 

1.6 Activate work zone and cloud identity services 

1.7 Create work zone key and enable cloud foundry 

 

 

 

 

 1.8 Create destinations 

Create the below destinations in BTP 

1.8.1 Create a design time destination with basic authentication. This is the destination which sends the content from S/4HANA system to work zone. Also, give the client property in the destination. 

1.8.2 Create runtime destination with proxy type internet and no authentication. This is the destination which is used to retrieve the data from S/4 system in runtime. 

1.8.3 Create private cloud destinations with principal propagation. This is the destination used to retrieve nominations through the SAP cloud connector. 

1.8.4 Create single sign on destination with principal propagation 

1.8.5 Create Navigation destination with details of work zone 

1.8.6Create RFC destination with basic authentication for identity provisioning 

 

 1.9 Create content Provider 

A content provider is simply a system or source that supplies data or content to another application. The receiving system uses this provided content to show data, answer questions, or perform actions. 

 

 1.10 Add S/4HANA private cloud domain to trusted domain names in both BTP and IAS 

 2. Cloud connector 

In the cloud connector we need to create a subaccount for Joule by providing the BTP subaccount details such as region, subaccount id, Display name email and password. 

 

 

Create one HTTPS connection and an RFC connection to the backend S/4HANA system and make sure the HTTPS connection is set with principal propagation and connection is working to the backend. 

Tip: Principal propagation configuration is a mandatory step for Joule to work with S/4HANA private cloud and make sure this configuration is completed and working.  

 3. Cloud identity services 

Configure cloud identity services to create source and destination systems. 

We need to add source and target systems to the cloud identity services to process the user roles and groups in the SAP work zone. 

Source system and target systems creating Json script are available on the below page 

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/configure-identity-provisioning-service-a6cf317ecede4fa78c57be07219cee1a 

Once the systems are created, the next step is to run the read/sync job which will create the users and corresponding roles and groups in the work zone to support Joule functionality.  

 

 4. S/4HANA system 

4.1 Create a technical user with the roles SAP_BC_JSF_COMMUNICATION_RO Profiles and profile SAP_ALL. This user is used for communication of joule with S/4 HANA system wherever basic authentication is used. 

4.2 Create Technical and Business Catalog in S/4HANA system. First, create the technical catalog with the details below and add this technical catalog to the business catalog. 

 

Field 

Value 

Application Type 

SAP UI5 Fiori App 

Semantic Object 

Shell 

Action 

plugin 

SAPUI5 Component ID 

sap.das.webclientplugin.s4 

ICF Path 

URL with Joule application’s hostname, and with /resources/public/webclient/s4 appended 

Suppress Tile 

Checked 

Application Component ID 

CA-FLP-ABA 

Target Application Title 

Joule 

Information 

Optional: Enter a description of your plug-in. 

Device Types 

Select the device or devices that are supported by your plug-in, e.g. desktop or phone. The plug-in will only be shown on these selected devices. 

Parameters 

Define parameters that you want to pass to the plug-in component by entering a name and a default value for each parameter. 

 4.3 Create a role in the system and add this business catalog to the role. 

This role is required for all the users who are using joule to see the joule icon in the Fiori Launchpad. Assign this role to the Joule users. 

 4.4 Activate OData services. Identify the list of OData services which are required to be activated in the system based on the joule capabilities and make sure the respective ICF services are also activated. 

4.5 Expose roles from CDM3. List all the roles based on the joule capabilities that are being used and expose all those roles to BTP. 

Once the roles are exposed, we can see these roles in the content manager of BTP work zone after updating the channel manager. 

Assign the roles to the users. Make sure the roles based on Joule capabilities are assigned to the users who are using Joule. 

This summarizes the complete end-to-end configuration required to activate SAP Joule for S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. 

Joule Icon will be available as below in the Fiori launchpad and we can login with the IAS credentials.

entry.title: Getting started with Joule-For ABAP Developers
entry.content:
Getting started with Joule-For ABAP Developers

Recently, I got the opportunity to attend a hands-on workshop session organized by SAP on Joule for developers.  The session covered its integration with SAP Build as well as ABAP. As I am into ABAP, here’s a quick startup blog on Joule for developers-ABAP. Let’s quickly get to the overview of Joule.

What is Joule?

Joule is an AI copilot inside SAP, that understands normal conversations, so it’s your smart coworker in SAP that operates on cloud (BTP) and can help in fetching quick data, generating reports and even suggesting code or code modifications, which in turn makes your life much easier.

Key Features:

  • Conversational Interface
  • Integration with SAP Apps
  • Enterprise Ready
  • Tailored for your business
  • Automatic updates
  • Create custom package

Benefits:

  • Faster work
  • Smarter Insights
  • Better outcomes
  • Full control

With that overview in place, let's begin with how we can use Joule while working on the developments in Eclipse.

Add Joule in Eclipse

       1. Create Package

  • First step is to create a package using below steps:
  • In the cloud system in eclipse under Favourite packages, right click on ZLOCAL package.
  • Create a new sub package with your unique group id.
  •  Maintain the required information like package name and description and click next.
  • Next screen will display Package type, S/W component and Transport layer.
  • Select Package Type “Development” and click “Next”.
  • Create/Select the required TR and click on “Finish”.
  • Package will get created.

          

        2. Create Artifacts

        Created Odata service from scratch for a travel application using        /DMO/TRAVEL_DATA and /DMO/BOOKING_DATA structures.  Steps are given below:

  • Right click on the package.
  • Select “Generate ABAP Repository Objects”.

         

  • Select “OData UI service from scratch”.

       

  • Click ‘Next’ and select the required package.
  • Click ‘Next’ to finish and enable the joule.
  • Joule is now active and will be displayed on right side as shown below:

How to use Joule

We can give prompts for Joule to create objects in the system. For example, to create the application, paste the below prompt in Joule window:

“Create a transaction application for travel management. Create the entity Travel based on the structure /DMO/TRAVEL_DATA. The second entity is Booking based on /DMO/BOOKING_DATA. “

Joule will respond by displaying the list of objects that will be created. If there are not further modifications, we can just click on “Accept”:

Then, click on next and select the previously created TR and click on “Finish”.

The application for travel management will get created and in the project explorer all the generated objects will get displayed:

We can also give further prompt to add new fields, or if we need any other modifications. Make sure to click Accept every time you are adding new objects. Also, before continuing and generating the RAP BO, make sure you check for all the required fields and objects in your data model.

Explaining Artifacts

Joule can even provide the details of the artifacts. So, if we need Joule to explain any of the objects,

  • Right click on the artifact that we want the details for, Select Joule->Explain.
  • Joule will be displayed on right with all the required explanation about the artifact selected.
  • Here one can ask further questions as well.

Notes:

Generated objects should always end with suffix “###” (follow naming conventions)-replace ### with your group ID.

References:

SAP Help Portal

abap-platform-rap120/exercises/ex01/README.md at main · SAP-samples/abap-platform-rap120 · GitHub

entry.title: Why Vectorized Master Data is Critical for AI on SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Why Most AI Agents Fail with SAP Data

AI Agents are rapidly becoming part of enterprise landscapes, and SAP ECC and S/4HANA are obvious targets for automation. However, what we see in the market today is concerning.

Most agentic solutions attempt to consume SAP data through custom coding. This approach creates three major problems:

  1. High development and maintenance costs

  2. Multiple, inefficient calls to the SAP backend

  3. Mass data extraction, where AI Agents pull entire tables just to find a few relevant records

In many of the solutions we reviewed, including agentic SDKs integrations such as Joule, n8n, ChatGPT, and Claude, AI Agents frequently fail, time out, or request all records from SAP ERP systems with minimal filtering. This is inefficient, risky, and completely unnecessary.

At Skybuffer AI, we believe there is a better way.

The Foundation: Preparing SAP Data for AI Consumption

Data preparation is the key to successful AI-driven automation. While topics like data silos and data quality are well known, they cannot be fully solved overnight. Instead of fighting this reality, Skybuffer AI introduces a simple and reliable data layer that AI Agents can consume efficiently.

Skybuffer AI uses SAP master data vectorization to enable fast, accurate access to SAP ECC and S/4HANA data from agentic workflows. Any SAP master data table, including views and CDS views, can be vectorized and materialized using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Key capabilities include:

  • Support for full and delta loads

  • Near real-time synchronization with SAP

  • A scalable, AI-ready representation of SAP master data

 Pic. 1 Skybuffer AI – SAP Data Vectorization Configuration

Performance at Enterprise Scale

A common concern is performance. Vectorizing SAP master data row by row would indeed be slow, if done sequentially.

Skybuffer AI solves this with parallel embedding execution, allowing vectorization at enterprise scale. On servers with 8 GPUs, Skybuffer AI can process up to 1 million records in 30 minutes. That is scalable in case even faster vectorization solution is needed.

More importantly, once initial vectorization is complete, a self-healing delta mechanism ensures that only new or changed records are processed. This keeps the data current without impacting performance.

Business Value: Why This Approach Matters

The benefits are immediate and measurable:

  • No coding for intelligent master data search

  • No multiple calls to SAP backend systems

  • No full-table reads triggered by AI Agents

  • Faster, more reliable AI-driven processes

Consider a real-world scenario:
A vendor invoice arrives by email.

Pic. 2 Real Consumption-Based Invoice Example

The AI Agent reads the email and attachment, extracts the vendor name exactly as written on the invoice, and needs the corresponding SAP vendor number. Instead of querying SAP repeatedly or scanning entire tables, the Agent performs one single RAG search against vectorized SAP master data.

Within milliseconds, the correct vendor record is returned. It is accurate, up to date, and ready for posting in SAP.

Pic. 3 Skybuffer AI – Fast and Reliable SAP Data Search Using Data Vectorization

No coding. No overload. No hallucinations.

Applicable Across Many SAP Use Cases

The same approach works seamlessly across multiple scenarios, including:

  • Finding SAP users or business objects by name, email address, or other attributes

  • Creating Sales Orders in SAP from customer Purchase Orders

  • Resolving customer and material master data automatically

  • Creating Bills of Materials and routings from Excel files managed by R&D teams

  • Posting Service Entry Sheets

  • Rapidly enabling new use cases by simply nominating tables for vectorization

If the data exists in SAP, it can be prepared for AI consumption.

Built-In Authorization and Security

Security is not an afterthought.

Skybuffer AI applies the same concept used in AI assistants for Teams, Copilot, and Joule, so vectorized data accessed by users with an additional safeguard. Once the AI Agent selects relevant records via RAG, Skybuffer AI retrieves those records directly from SAP using SSO within the active conversation session, before providing data to the user.

This ensures:

  • Users only see data they are authorized to access in SAP

  • Vectorized data never bypasses SAP authorization rules

  • Enterprise-grade compliance and governance

Seamless Integration with Existing AI Agents

Already running AI Agents and just need access to SAP data?

Skybuffer AI provides an MCP Server, allowing your existing agentic solutions to consume vectorized SAP data without replacing your current platform. This makes Skybuffer AI an enabler, not a disruptor.

 Pic. 4 Skybuffer AI – MCP Server for Integration with Agentic SDK

Flexible Deployment: Cloud or On-Premise

Skybuffer AI is built on SAP HANA and can be deployed:

  • On-premise within your own infrastructure

  • In your SAP BTP tenant

A modern SAP UI5 user interface ensures an intuitive and productive user experience for both IT and business users.

Conclusion

SAP ECC and S/4HANA master data vectorization is the missing link between SAP and AI Agents.

With Skybuffer AI, enterprises can:

  • Eliminate coding

  • Avoid hallucinations

  • Reduce SAP backend load

  • Enable fast, secure, and reliable AI-driven processes

This is how SAP data becomes truly AI-ready.

entry.title: A minimum viable testing model for Document Grounding of HR Policies with Joule in three phases
entry.content:
Phase 1: Content Readiness

Before testing Joule, the documents themselves must be tested. Document Grounding cannot compensate for unclear language, conflicting versions or missing context.

Each document intended for grounding should be reviewed against a simple content readiness checklist:

  • Is this document the single source of truth or do parallel versions exist in other locations?
  • Is the language clear enough that a human could answer common employee questions without interpretation or assumptions?
  • Are headings descriptive, and does each section clearly answer a specific question?
  • Are rules, exceptions and local deviations explicitly described rather than implied?
  • Is the document tagged with accurate and consistent metadata aligned with SAP SuccessFactors context, such as country, legal entity or employee group?

Issues identified in this phase should be treated as content or governance problems, not Joule problems.

Phase 2: Controlled testing & Negative and boundary testing

Once content readiness is established, testing should move to controlled scenarios that reflect real employee behavior.

Start by building a small set of representative HR questions that employees already ask. For each question, define what a correct answer looks like before testing Joule. This establishes an objective baseline.

Include both factual and procedural questions, for example:

  • “How many annual vacation days do I have?”
  • “How many days of parental leave am I entitled to?”
  • “How do I change my bank account details?”

Each response should be evaluated against the following criteria:

  • Is the answer factually correct according to the policy?
  • Does it reference the correct document and version?
  • Does it respect relevant context such as country or legal entity?
  • Is the answer understandable and actionable for a typical employee?

If any of these checks fail, the issue should be traced back to document structure, naming, metadata, or content clarity. While retrieval and ranking mechanisms are handled by the system, their limitations may surface as apparent content issues and should be addressed there first.

In addition to controlled testing, negative and boundary testing is essential:

  • Ask questions that should not have an answer, such as confidential topics or policies that are not grounded.
  • Ask vague or ambiguous questions and verify that Joule asks for clarification rather than providing an overly confident response.
  • Ask the same question using different wording and confirm that the answer remains consistent.

This phase validates not only correctness, but also restraint. In an HR context, an incorrect or overly confident answer is often more harmful than no answer at all.

Phase 3: Update and lifecycle testing

Accurate answers at one point in time are not sufficient. HR policies change and Document Grounding must reflect those changes reliably.

Lifecycle testing should validate the end-to-end update process:

  • Make a small but meaningful change to a grounded document.
  • Verify that the update is reflected after the expected synchronization window, typically within 24 hours.
  • Confirm that Joule no longer references outdated information.
  • Ensure that archived or superseded documents are not used in responses.

This phase tests whether document versioning, archiving rules and SharePoint configuration work under real conditions. From a risk perspective, outdated answers are often more leaving than missing answers, especially in regulated or legally sensitive HR areas.

Conclusion

Document Grounding with Joule is not a feature to be tested in isolation. It is a system-level capability that depends on content quality, metadata discipline and lifecycle governance.

A sound testing approach reflects core SAP Business AI principles: reliability over novelty, explainability over opacity, and business trust over technical experimentation. By validating content readiness, controlled behavior and lifecycle integrity, organizations can move from experimenting with AI-generated answers to confidently deploying them in daily HR interactions.

In practice, this approach shifts the focus from “Does Joule work?” to the more important question: “Is our HR knowledge ready for AI to act on it?”

entry.title: The Secret Shopper for SAP Agents: Why Enterprise AI Needs a Reality Check with Int4 Suite
entry.content:
The enterprise software world is currently “a bit” obsessed with "Agentic AI". We’re moving away from rigid, click-here-then-there workflows toward SAP Joule agents, autonomous entities that can reason, use tools, and execute complex business processes like the ones show in the figure below: 

Figure 1 - SAP Joule Agents 

But as we hand the keys of our SAP S/4HANA systems over to these digital coworkers, we face a fundamental crisis: The Death of Determinism. For decades, software testing followed a simple rule: Input X + Logic F = Output Y. It was predictable. With AI agents, that’s gone. An agent might solve the same problem three different ways on three different days. This creates a "Verification Gap" where traditional testing fails. If your AI agent "hallucinates" a successful transaction that never actually hits the database, your supply chain doesn't just slow down, it breaks. Here is why your enterprise needs a new way to test, and how Int4 Suite is stepping in as an Enterprise AI validator or in some business scenarios as a "Secret Shopper" for the AI era.

The Hallucination Trap: Why "Polite" AI Isn't Enough for Enterprise AI 

Most AI testing tools today are Guardrail Platforms. They are like bouncers at a club: they make sure the AI doesn't say anything offensive, leak a credit card number, or succumb to a prompt injection attack.

While essential for security, these tools have a massive blind spot: Functional Integrity. If SAP Joule Agents tells you, "I’ve processed that sales order for you!" with a polite digital smile, but it actually failed to map the tax jurisdiction code correctly in SAP S/4HANA, the "security" tools won't catch it. They validate the Tool Call (what the agent intended to do), but they don't validate the Tool Execution (what actually happened in the database).

The "Secret Shopper" Scenario: Order-to-Cash

Imagine you want to check the quality of service at a high-end retail store. You don't just ask the manager if the staff is good; you send in a Secret Shopper, a person with a specific script who tests the system's limits and reports back on exactly what happened.

In the world of SAP S/4HANA, Int4 Suite acts as that Secret Shopper for the Order-to-Cash (O2C) process. Here’s how the "Mission" looks:

  1. The Trigger: A customer sends an email with an attached PDF order.

  2. The Agent's Job: SAP Joule (the AI agent) must read the email, parse the PDF, and autonomously create a Sales Order, an Outbound Delivery, and an Invoice in SAP S/4HANA.

Figure 2 - Order to Cash process started by a PDF inside an e-mail, processed by the AI Agent completely 

  1. The Int4 Suite "Mission":

  • Fetch & Fabricate: Int4 Suite fetches a real historical email and PDF from your system using its Robotic Crawler. It then dynamically changes the values (unique qualifier like the Order reference, etc.) so the test is unique and won't clash with existing data.

  • The Sting: Int4 Suite resends this unique "mystery" order to the AI agent.

  • The Deep Audit: This is where Int4 Suite shines. While other tools just watch the "chat," Int4 Suite goes into the SAP S/4HANA backend. It validates the resulting documents up to the field level.

Figure 3 - Replication of the original process by this time completely run by Int4 Suite and validated in the SAP S/4HANA DB. 

Did the agent correctly calculate the net value? Is the shipping point correct? Did the invoice trigger the right accounting document? Int4 Suite compares the agent's work against historical "gold standard" documents to ensure 100% accuracy.

Figure 4 - SAP S/4HANA DB validation of a sales order posting 

The FWE Model: A New Standard for AI Validation

To truly trust an AI agent, you need a Functional Workflow Execution (FWE) model. This is the architectural loop that Int4 Suite has perfected:

  • Technical Flow Implementation: Setting up the "harness" where the agent lives.

  • Test Case Definition: Defining what "success" actually looks like - Order posted with a certain number of lines, Delivery posted with certain quantities, etc..

Figure 5 - Test Workflow definition inside Int4 Suite 

  • Dynamic Data Fabrication: Using the Robotic Crawler to mine historical messages and "seed" the test environment with valid, complex data.

  • Agent Execution: Letting the AI run wild in a deterministic "sandbox."

  • Backend Validation: Programmatically inspecting SAP S/4HANA database entries, IDocs, and API responses to verify the "side effects" of the AI’s actions.

Why Int4 Suite’s approach is Unique? 

While the market is flooded with "AI Security" startups, they lack the "plumbing" to talk to SAP. Int4 Suite was born in the world of SAP integration (PI/PO, CPI). It speaks the language of IDocs, OData, APIs in general.

We are witnessing a shift from deterministic chains to probabilistic agents. You can't test a probabilistic agent with a spreadsheet and a prayer.

If you are deploying SAP Joule, you need a validator that doesn't just listen to what the agent says, but verifies what the agent did. By leveraging service virtualization and deep backend inspection, Int4 Suite ensures that your "Secret Shopper" tests don't just find hallucinations, they build a foundation of enterprise-grade trust.

Ready to send a Secret Shopper into your S/4HANA system? It’s time to move beyond the chat bubble and into the database.

Further Learning on Int4 Suite: Avoiding Project Delays

If you want to dive deeper into how to decouple your project timeline from external risks, SAP provides a dedicated learning path on this exact topic.

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content:
Several people have reached out to me this week to describe the new way you set up document grounding with Joule Studio. So here goes.

What is Document Grounding

Many of you may know about Document Grounding, but for those who don't here's a very brief explanation.

  1. The basic way we use AI is to send a prompt to an LLM (a set of "indexed" information).
  2. If we want the LLM to take into account additional information it may not have, we can provide "context" (though the amount of "context" you are allowed to send may be constrained).

One of those pieces of context may come from a set of documents (e.g., housed in SharePoint or in the SAP BTP Object Store service). In order to use those documents as context we must perform Document Grounding, which takes the documents, "chunks" them into small pieces, and then "embeds" them so they can be used as context in our AI requests.

In Joule Studio, when we create agents, we essentially specify an LLM to handle specific types of prompts, and then provide context and instructions for what we want the agent to do.

The "Old" Way in Joule Studio

The old way we performed Document Grounding in Joule Studio was to go into AI Core and create a resource group, connect that resource group to a content store (e.g., the place we store the documents), and have AI Core chunk and embed the documents so we could use the content within an agent or for use when sending a prompt to AI Core. Joule Studio would be configured to connect with a specific AI Core, and the developer of an agent would type in the name of a resource group in AI Core to use with their agent.

Here we can see in the SAP AI Launchpad that we are connected to the "dbw" resource, and we have created a "pipeline" with documents.

If we click inside, we can see that this pipeline has 4 documents, each chunked and embedded. 

But doing this required going into the SAP AI Launchpad, creating Generic Secrets by encoding credentials in Base64, and several more steps in tools we may not be familiar with.

Joule Studio still makes use of the same mechanism in AI Core, but now takes care of creating all the artifacts behind the scene (and enables some new capabilities).  

 

1. Prerequisites

You need an instance of SAP AI Core and an S3-compatible document store such as the Object Store service in BTP. I won't go into setting these up, but you can find out more information here:

  • AI Core
  • Object Store

If you need more information, leave a comment.

Note you can define many instances of AI Core and Object Store to be used with Joule Studio.

 

2. Destinations

You need to set up destinations to AI Core and Object Store on both your SAP Build tenant and your Joule tenant. 

AI Core Destination

Get the service key of your AI Core instance, and create a destination as shown below.

Append /oauth/token to the url value of the service key and use this for the destination's Token Service URL.

Add the additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-ai-core and set it to true. This makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

Object Store Destination

Similarly, get the service key for the object store service instance and set the following destination fields with the corresponding service field value:

Destination FieldService Key Field
URLaccess_key_id
Client IDhost (add https://)
Client Secretsecret_access_key
Token Service URLhost (add https://)

Add the following additional properties:

Additional PropertyValue
regionregion value from service key
bucketbucket value from service key
usernameusername value from service key
typeS3
sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store
true

The additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

3. Set Up in Control Tower

In the Control Tower, the SAP Build admin will decide:

  • From which object stores to create Document Grounding.
  • In which AI Core instances to create these Document Grounding pipelines.

The Control Tower now has a Joule section, including a Document Grounding tile so the admin can create Document Grounding and make it available to Joule Studio developers.

Click the Document Grounding tile. You can now create sets of Document Grounding.

Note that while in the SAP AI Launchpad you could create different pipelines with different sets of documents in the same resource group, here each object store will create a separate resource group.

Click Add.

Give the resource group a name.

Select the AI Core instance in which to create the resource group.

And finally select the object store whose documents you want to ground.

Click Add.

The status of the resource group will be Pending. 

After about a minute (depending on the size of the documents), the status will change to Completed.

(Early on, I occasionally got Error messages, or Pending simply remained for a long time, and sometimes they would alternate between those messages. In such cases, make sure the destinations are configured properly and make sure the documents in the Object Store are not corrupted.)

If you now look in SAP AI Launchpad, and go to SAP AI Core Administration > Resource Groups, you will see a new resource group whose name is the name you specified (without spaces) with a Unix timestamp appended.

Though the resource group should immediately appear on the Resource Groups page, it may take a few extra minutes for the resource group to appear on the Workspaces page. 

Once it does, you can select it and see the pipeline and Document Grounding inside the resource group. 

 

4. Add Document Grounding to Your Agent 

Now that the admin has set up a resource group and triggered the document grounding for a set of documents, developers of Joule Studio agents can use them in their agents.

Inside an agent, the developer can specify tools, including documents. Select Add Tools > Documents.

This opens a dialogue to specify which resource group created by the admin to use. Specify a name for the documents (as seen in the agent) and a description to help the agent know when to use them.

Then select from among the resource groups created by the admin.

Advantages

The advantages of this method are:

  • Admins and developers no longer have to work in AI Launchpad, including creating Generic Secrets and dealing with Base64 encoding of credentials.
  • Admins decide what document grounding gets used in Joule Studio agents.
    • From the look of the UI, admins will eventually be able to assign a resource group to a specific environment, giving admins even more control
  • Developers have a predefined set of  resource groups to choose from, using a dropdown list.
  • More than one AI Core instance and more than one Object Store instance can be used to define document grounding for a Joule Studio.

Note that this method creates a single document grounding pipeline in each resource group it creates; using AI Launchpad, you can create multiple pipelines in a single resource group.

There may be more advantages and limitations. Please add a comment with your opinion about this feature, or anything I missed.

entry.title: Chapter 2 || SAP Joule: Interaction Patterns of SAP Joule
entry.content:
SAP Joule Series:
Chapter 1 || SAP Joule: The central nervous system for Business
Chapter 2 || SAP Joule: Interaction Patterns of SAP Joule

Joule Capabilities are categorized into different Interaction patterns.

1. Informational Interaction Pattern:

The informational pattern provides knowledge-based results. These are, for example, policy-related questions. This can be based on SAP-owned content, such as SAP Help Pages, or could be a customer-owned content as well, by integrating the SAP Document Grounding services with Joule.

 

 

2. Navigational Interaction Pattern:

Joule makes it easy for users to reach the right SAP application or screen, so they can manage business processes on their own. With Joule, users can jump straight to what they need, which is ideal for those who aren’t familiar with SAP’s navigation.

 

3. Transactional Interaction Pattern

Joule gives users a direct entry point to access SAP’s backend systems. They can start and manage business processes just by using natural language and generative AI. For example, reviewing and approving purchase orders, creating new job postings, or handling any other create, read, update, or delete tasks. All the SAP's cloud products are now building content packages for Joule to support the most essential interactions for the users.

 

4. Analytical Interaction Pattern

This pattern aims to provides insights and data analysis capabilities. Users can ask questions related to business metrics, trends, and performance indicators, and Joule will provide relevant insights from the SAP Analytics Cloud system.

entry.title: My highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release
entry.content:
Welcome to 2026 and welcome to my SAP Cloud ERP 2602 product release highlights! This blog post guides you through the key improvements of the 2602 release of SAP Cloud ERP, focusing on how they support customers in running and evolving their core business processes. And it was again not easy to decide what to declare as highlights amongst the large number of innovations delivered. It's our 34th major release over the years, and I have collected an interesting range across functional, foundational and user experience capabilities. And of course, the AI journey continues to boost both well-known and new ERP processes to a new levels. We're all in on AI.

I wish the team would have granted me more space to talk you through all innovation shipped with the 2602 release , take this blog post as an appetizer for our team’s deep dive blogs per line of business. Prefer video over text? Take a look at my product update video, where my digital twin guides you through the key highlights. 

 

A new operating model for integrated business processes 

With the first release of 2026, we walk the talk of our SAP Business Suite and introduce a range of SAP-managed Integrated Business Processes, removing the complexity of integrating and monitoring multiple cloud solutions from our customer's and partner's activity list. We have carefully listened to your wishes and SAP delivers co-provisioning, functional and technical integration, including lifecycle management, allowing these activities to move in the background while customers focus on their core business. By shifting responsibility for aligned system provisioning, functional and technical integration, and lifecycle management from customers to SAP, we reduce complexity behind the scenes and enables a more seamless suite experience.

* Click here to access the links mentioned in the slide above

As an initial step, release 2602 delivers SAP-managed integration for two critical end-to-end processes as part of an Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. In Workforce Management, SAP provides SAP-managed provisioning and integration between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, supporting a streamlined Recruit-to-Retire process with consistent employee and financial data from day one. For Operational Procurement, integrated processes across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Ariba Buying, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management simplify Procure-to-Pay activities and support a more unified procurement landscape.

These capabilities are enabled by blueprint-based provisioning, which changes how solution instances are deployed, integrated, and managed across the run phase. Instead of manual setup, customers can activate selective solutions or in the future complete suites that are provisioned and come already fully integrated together. Guided by a new suite experience in SAP for Me and based on SAP landscape modeling best practices, SAP applies a desired-state-based reconciliation to ensure transparency, consistency, and long-term stability across the application landscape.

 

AI innovations

SAP Joule for Consultants: Practical enhancements for your everyday project work

With this first release of year 2026, SAP Joule for Consultants continues to mature as a day-to-day companion for project focused workers, offering efficient access to trusted content, better transparency, and smoother workflows – on demand. A new SAP Joule for Consultants console brings ‘What’s New’ release notes, an integrated prompt library, and, where relevant, administrative insights such as usage metrics and system settings into one central entry point, helping teams stay aligned with current innovations.

 

 

Joule now also surfaces SAP Notes and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) directly within conversations, based on existing customer entitlements. This allows consultants to reference validated SAP guidance without leaving their context, while administrators retain control through standard s-user assignments. Usability improvements further support efficient work: Quick links simplify navigation across Joule features, the conversation character limit has been increased to 10,000 characters to accommodate larger inputs such as code or detailed scenarios, and public SAP content sources have been refreshed and expanded.

Enhanced citation visibility improves transparency by clearly indicating the origin of information, including public web sources when applicable.

 

Finally, the initial ingestion of SAP Signavio Process Navigator reference content lays the groundwork for more architecture-aware guidance in future releases.

 

Finance

Accounting Accruals Agent (beta)

In the dynamic landscape of financial management, the introduction of the beta version of Accounting Accruals Agent marks a thoughtful stride towards empowering finance professionals with innovative tools tailored for efficiency. This intelligent agent draws from AI-driven capabilities to meticulously craft accrual proposals, transforming the traditionally labor-intensive process into a streamlined operation. By analyzing accounting policy documents, sifting through historical data, and executing precise calculations, this agent reduces the substantial time accountants typically spend during period-end accruals. The newfound simplicity in the ‘Manage Accrual Proposals’ app not only enhances the speed of reviewing and posting proposals but also offers detailed, AI-backed explanations for each calculated entry. This ensures that general ledger accountants gain not just time but also trust in AI’s role in augmenting their decision-making processes, thereby enabling a smoother and more efficient period-end close. This feature is going to be made generally available in SAP Cloud ERP 2602.

 

SAP User Experience

AI-assisted task automation (beta)

In everyday work, many tasks in SAP Cloud ERP follow the same patterns: Reviewing data, triggering follow-up steps, or keeping processes moving. With AI-assisted task automation, SAP introduces smart helpers that support users exactly in these moments. Built with generative AI and embedded directly in My Home, these helpers can take over routine steps within SAP applications while keeping users in control whenever decisions or data changes are required. Instead of replacing human judgement, the focus is on reducing manual effort and helping users progress through their tasks more smoothly. Over time, this creates a more natural way of working with automation, one that adapts to real user needs and daily workflows. Customers interested in shaping this capability early can join the beta program to explore the feature and provide feedback that will influence future AI-driven experiences in SAP Cloud ERP.

Check out this link to sign up for the beta testing and shape the future of AI innovations: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/4086 

 

Retail

Assortment module management 

Many non-retail industries integrate retail capabilities into their ERP systems to enhance customer services and collaboration, even in B2B. Most organizations today are expected to react faster to changing customer expectations while keeping operations efficient and scalable. This requires tools that simplify everyday work for planners and merchandisers, reduce operational friction, and make it easier to translate data and insights into action. In this context, intelligent assistance within core retail processes becomes increasingly important, especially where decisions around assortments directly influence customer experience and business outcomes.

In the area of Retail, Joule’s integration into assortment module management supports planners by making common tasks more accessible and less time-consuming. Instead of navigating multiple screens, users can rely on natural language interactions to create, update, or terminate assortments directly within the application. This reduces dependency on deep technical knowledge and helps teams complete routine tasks with greater confidence and efficiency. As a result, merchandising and category managers can spend less time on operational steps and more time focusing on assortment strategy and customer-centric planning.

For more information, please consult SAP Help Portal.

 

Asset Management

Maintenance notification creation and screening with Joule

In Asset Management, keeping maintenance processes running smoothly depends on timely and accurate notifications, often created under time pressure and by users outside of specialized maintenance roles. With Joule integrated into the maintenance notification process in SAP Cloud ERP, creating and screening notifications becomes more straightforward and accessible. Users can describe an issue in natural language and capture key details such as the technical object, priority, and description without navigating complex transaction flows. Moreover, users can access notifications in the ‘Manage Maintenance Notification’ SAP Fiori app (F5777), enabling quick acceptance and conversion into maintenance orders within a single conversational context. As a result, operators spend less time on documentation, while maintenance teams and managers benefit from clearer, more consistent information to plan and execute maintenance activities effectively.

 

SAP Activate innovations

SAP Activate introduces several innovations for the 2602 release, starting with a dedicated activation and implementation guidance for customers adopting SAP-managed integrations in the Early Adopter Care program, mentioned earlier.

Customers implementing SAP Cloud ERP will continue to benefit from easier access to implementation information with Joule, which is embedded in the ’Roadmap Viewer’ application on SAP for Me. Additionally, implementation teams can access up-to-date implementation guidance in nine languages: Chinese, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, and Spanish. Change your language preferences in SAP for Me to view content in another language.

Customers conducting the upgrade to the 2602 release can leverage the lean upgrade roadmap in the ‘Roadmap Viewer’ app or in SAP Cloud ALM to guide their team through the upgrade and post-upgrade activities. 

 

SAP Cloud ALM updates

In transformation projects, teams often invest a lot of time turning workshop outcomes, documents, and process discussions into structured requirements and test assets. With the latest updates in SAP Cloud ALM, this work becomes more streamlined across the project lifecycle. AI-assisted  requirements generation helps teams create initial requirements automatically based on Fit-to-Standard workshop transcripts, solution processes, and other project documentation, giving project members a solid starting point that can be reviewed and refined instead of built from scratch.

As project scopes evolve, requirements can now be moved easily between projects, supporting reuse and reducing duplication.

 

 Further enhancements focus on governance and test preparation.

New APIs for manual test cases, process hierarchies, and features make it easier to integrate SAP Cloud ALM into existing tool landscapes and automate project reporting or oversight. All SAP Cloud ALM APIs can be found on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

During test preparation, teams can now define where screenshots are required as test evidence, improving transparency and auditability during execution.

 

Updates to release assessment and scope dependency

Smarter upgrades in SAP Cloud ERP require a clear understanding of customer´s individually relevant applications and scope items. The release assessment and scope dependency (RASD) tool continues to evolve, incorporating customer feedback to make impact analysis more transparent and easier to work with. Recent updates simplify how assessment results are shared, allowing users to download content across all tiles, or selected ones, into a single ZIP file with structured Excel outputs that can be reviewed, filtered, and discussed across distributed project teams.

Beyond usability improvements, RASD now provides more precise guidance for upgrade decisions. The introduction of a successor view helps identify recommended follow-on apps, supporting smoother transition planning.

In addition, enhanced views in the personalized 'What’s New Viewer' clearly differentiate between activated, used, and impacted scope items, helping teams focus on what truly matters in their system.

Together, these enhancements support more informed discussions, reduce uncertainty during release preparation, and help teams approach upgrades with greater clarity and confidence.

 

Other innovations across various LoBs

Supply Chain Management – Warehouse management

Interface to warehouse automation systems for efficiently processing warehouse orders

In the evolving landscape of warehouse management, the integration of warehouse automation systems is set to significantly enhance operational efficiency. By seamlessly distributing warehouse orders to automated subsystems, businesses can ensure smooth and coordinated task execution. This interface not only sends out orders but also receives confirmations of warehouse tasks, creating a continuous feedback loop that ensures transparency and efficiency. Such integration significantly cuts down manual intervention, allowing for a more streamlined process that minimizes errors and enhances productivity. The main advantage lies in the ability to process warehouse orders more efficiently, capitalizing on automation to handle tasks that were once labor-intensive. This means warehouse operations can maintain a high level of accuracy while handling greater volumes, ultimately enhancing the overall supply chain performance and reliability.

 

 

Manufacturing

Production order combination enablement

In the Manufacturing line of business, we are happy to introduce production order combination enablement, which offers a practical solution to streamline operations and enhance efficiency. By merging identical operations from different production orders into a single consolidated order, manufacturers can optimize their processes right from the ‘Manage Production Orders’ app. This functionality allows for the creation, maintenance, and confirmation of combined orders, which in turn supports effective cost distribution and settlement through new event-based costing. By reducing setup times and overhead charges, this approach not only increases production throughput but also achieves considerable cost savings. This feature empowers manufacturers to focus their efforts on boosting output while maintaining a keen eye on cost efficiency, creating a more agile and responsive production environment.

 

Professional Services

Intercompany cost allocations reconciliation review booklet

In the Professional Services domain, the enhancement of the ‘Intercompany Review Booklet’ app offers a significant boost in transparency and traceability for intercompany cost allocations. By displaying the complete end-to-end document flow, this app helps reconcile management accounting postings with billing and accounts receivable documents. This comprehensive view is invaluable during closing procedures, as it allows businesses to ensure their data's completeness by clearly identifying services and expenses that have been billed, are partially billed, or remain unbilled. Furthermore, the app provides audit-relevant information on billed intercompany services, offering businesses the assurance and documentation needed for clear internal and external audits. This capability aids organizations in maintaining robust financial processes while enhancing their ability to track and manage intercompany transactions efficiently. Starting with release 2602, the report will include an enhanced breakdown of billed entries, tracing them all the way to the receiver FI journal entry/affiliated expenses.  

 

Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In the domain of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management, enhancing the integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP was one of the items discussed and designed in our customer product councils. This innovation facilitates seamless synchronization of project plan data between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enabling a more cohesive project management experience. Users can manually trigger updates to project dates in SAP Cloud ERP, ensuring that information remains current and accurate. Furthermore, the automated bi-directional synchronization of project plan data significantly reduces the manual effort involved in data maintenance, allowing teams to focus on strategic initiatives. With greater scope control and improved integration, organizations can enjoy comprehensive visibility of critical information across different solutions, thus enhancing data quality and operational efficiency. This development empowers project managers with the tools needed to effectively monitor and control project progress, fostering better decision-making and resource allocation throughout the project lifecycle.

As SAP Cloud ERP continues to evolve, these innovations aim to support more efficient processes, clearer guidance, and a smoother experience across implementations and upgrades.
